sourceDesc.bibl: Nelly. Buenos Aires: Compañía Sud-Americana de Billetes de Banco, 1896.

encodingDesc.p: The original image files have been processed with OCR. The software used was ABBYY Finereader 12 Professional, with Spanish as recognition language.
Where applicable, the orthography has been modernized, typos have been corrected and gaps filled.

p.quote: The scene of Nelly, a novel of the supernatural and the subconscious, is an old secluded house where a group of men are spending a few days of leisure. A succession of mysterious happenings soon takes place: the delirium of one of the vacationers who is so trasported by his inner thoughts that he carries on a dialogue with his dead wife Nelly; an old man's apparition that requests his grandson to examine some worn maps and manuscripts; and a woman's anguished groans echoing through the walls.
p.bibl: Lichtblau, Myron (1959), The Argentine novel in the nineteenth century, pp. 114-115. Cited by Lichtblau, Myron. The Argentine Novel: an annotated bibliography. Lanham, Maryland, 1997, p. 483.

p.quote: El desarrollo es equilibrado, sigue un movimiento natural y logra por ello envolver la atención del lector sin reducirla al simple objetivo de descubrir el desenlace. El ambiente y los problemas se imponen a la intriga. La atmósfera [...] se logra desde el primer instante, por la sola pintura del caserón donde ha de comenzar el relato.
p.bibl: Pagés Larraya, Antonio (ed.). "Estudio preliminar". Cuentos fantásticos, p. 85. Cited by Lichtblau, Myron. The Argentine Novel: an annotated bibliography. Lanham, Maryland, 1997, p. 482.
